0.02.text:
Good evening ladies and gentlemen.  The
sharper eyed amongst you will have noticed that I'm not Kate Mosse.

6.46.text:
But I do have the excuse of being Greg
Mosse.

9.60.text: Kate is in London all of this week

11.46.text:
for the Bailey's women's prize for
fiction and is on stage as we speak at

15.04.text:
Royal Festival Hall and will be again
tomorrow night.

18.66.text: She is therefore simultaneously having a week of great excitement with the shortlisted authors for that prize

24.14.text: and great disappointment because she doesn't get to talk to Adrian Noble

27.90.text: about the magnificent production of "Ross" that he has blessed our theater with.

32.88.text: I saw it on Saturday night and half the audience stood up at the end to give it an ovation.

37.48.text: Last night, Monday night, the other half stood up.

40.45.text:
It is a truly magnificent show.  Can we
start with why "Ross", for you?

47.86.text: What was it that drew you to the show?

49.90.text: I was asked to do it!  I had actually read it quite a long time ago

56.56.text: when I was running the RSC but it didn't seem the right thing at that time.

61.90.text: Then I was rung out of the blue.  Would I like to do this play?

65.62.text:
Can you say what makes the show "not the
right thing to do"?

69.26.text: Well, there was a particular context then.  The question then was:- is it the right thing

76.64.text: for a classical theatre company to do that was mainly doing Shakespeare

80.10.text: and this wasn't great because there are no women in it.

82.87.text: So it wasn't a great thing to do.

84.43.text:
I've actually got on my list for later on
but I'll bring it forward:-

87.61.text:
Is it different having a company which
is solely men?

90.68.text: (Although there are many women on the creative team)

92.47.text: There are indeed and indeed on the support staff from the stage management etc.

101.35.text:
We're blessed by a group of 18 of the
loveliest blokes you'll ever meet

109.52.text: They're just gorgeous so there wasn't a sort of problem of "chaps".

116.91.text: No problem with macho stuff or testosterone but I suppose "yes" is the answer.

123.51.text:
I remember interviewing, a few years ago,
de la Martinez the conductor

127.80.text: who maintains that female orchestras are completely different from male orchestras.

134.08.text: Yes, I've never directed an all women production, I have to say.

140.22.text: Of course if you're doing Shakespeare

144.03.text: in the olden days, they tended to be biased towards men.

152.40.text:
Well tell me, just following on from
this,

156.15.text: "Why Ross?" was the question.  "Why now" for Ross, do you think?

161.70.text: The little addendum to "Why Ross?" is of course Joseph Fiennes who who is perfect for this.

168.32.text: He is sensational in the part, absolutely sensational.

175.17.text: I produced him in a play, I didn't direct it,  back at the pit in London.

180.24.text: "Son of man" in which he was magnificent.

183.00.text: So that was part of the answer to "Why Ross?"

186.66.text: There are certain plays that you can't do unless you've got people to do them.

190.83.text: You don't do "King Lear" unless you've got a "King Lear".  Well, you'd be nuts to anyway.

199.92.text: Are there any other parts within it which are equally essential to the casting as Joseph Fiennes as Ross?

211.40.text: but I was content to embark on the voyage with just Joseph.

218.00.text: Then we got Peter Polycarpou and Paul Freeman

223.20.text: and Mickey Feast and people like that

225.15.text: who came and joined the journey.

228.36.text: But the great emotional and spiritual journey of the play

235.54.text: is of course undertaken by Joe.

239.28.text: You've got to have someone who has got the chops and also the hunger to go on that journey.

247.26.text: When I saw it Saturday night with this standing ovation,

250.38.text: he and the whole company looked so gratified but also almost surprised.

256.46.text: Well, I think artists are naturally modest actually.

261.90.text: Mostly they are.  They were delighted that people were enjoying it so much.

265.92.text: Because it is quite rigorous.  To answer your second question, "Why now?"

271.95.text: It's very interesting because it's the first time in

277.56.text: the albeit brief performance history of the play in which

282.78.text: we have, I hope, explored the background issues of the play,

291.48.text: both from a Western point of view and also from an Arabic point of view.

297.16.text: Up until now, all of the Arabic parts were played by white people who put boot polish on their faces.

305.06.text: Nowadays we think that is absolutely extraordinary.

308.49.text: The play has a wonderful ability to offer up opportunities

321.04.text: in which one can explore the very complicated and quite often poignant situations

328.22.text: that occur in the Middle East.

331.66.text:
It's shocking, really, that many of the
problems, the horrors that we listen to

342.93.text: on the "Today Programme" in the morning or read in newspapers every day emanate from this period.

349.22.text: The dreadful decisions that were made in this period.

355.84.text:
So I listen to the news completely
differently now.

360.03.text:
They talked for example the other day
about Tafas

366.24.text: I think it was on the "Today Programme".  Something happened there in southern Syria.

370.50.text:
Of course Tafas is talked about in the
play and it's the village in which

375.27.text: 19 women were (quotes) "Obscenely bayoneted, 2 of whom were pregnant".

383.60.text: You think "Oh God!  They're still doing it!"

386.74.text: It is terrible, it is absolutely terrible, but do you think that the play makes a judgment?

392.76.text: It's not a play written yesterday,

396.00.text: it's not a play written in the context of today's politics,

399.18.text: but do you think it makes a judgment from it's time that still resonates today?

402.39.text: It's a great play, I think and therefore

407.10.text: I think it judges certain things.

410.37.text: I think it judges, implicitly the folly of power.

417.04.text: It judges the Sykes-Picot agreement which was the agreement made at the beginning of the first war

424.46.text: when two relatively minor bureaucrats, one French and one English,

429.42.text:
got a large map and a pencil and divided
up the Middle East.  That's what they did.

435.12.text: The lines you will see on the news tonight of Syria etc and Iraq

441.63.text: are the lines made by these two rather minor bureaucrats.

447.27.text:
So the play does indeed implicitly judge
them.

451.76.text: It was not a good way of dealing.

455.85.text: This this brings us to a question that is often asked about Rattigan.

461.62.text: How modern is he?  You are arguing that he's strongly modern in that his politics,

469.58.text: or the political questions that he raises still resonate.

472.78.text:
Then this comes from the second half
of his career.

475.92.text: The thing about Rattigan, simply, is that's

482.73.text: OK, I haven't said it yet, it's still in my head!

486.36.text: This play - in many, many respects Rattigan is a classicist.

492.75.text:
Our exploration of the play has led us
to really appreciate the structure,

501.03.text: the form of the play, the most extraordinary piece of writing of structure.

509.10.text: Lawrence was a great Greek scholar and in many ways,

514.56.text: (as I was saying to Joseph this afternoon)

518.44.text: in many ways Lawrence embodies the Renaissance ideal of the Greek mind in the Roman body.

530.64.text:
the more we have identified (if you like)
the classical skeleton upon which

537.48.text: the flesh of the play hangs,

541.74.text: the richer our work has become and our production has become.

546.82.text: So if you look here for example,

548.92.text: we've been able to exploit the marvelous space that's been created

556.38.text: since the building was rebuilt and renovated.

560.79.text: We can have what I would call an imaginative space.

566.73.text: A huge space that is filled (if you like) by the imagination.

575.55.text: So, on the one hand we've been able to make the play epic.

583.64.text: But at the same time, intimate and domestic when it needs to be.

586.59.text: So this new stage has served it frightfully well.

589.82.text: I think it's always very exciting when the depth of the stage is greater than the width of the stage.

593.94.text:
It seems to me to give a director
more scope

597.22.text: It does and it gives you a sense of the past, doesn't it?.

602.14.text: The past is behind us, isn't it?

605.20.text: The future is in front of us.

608.06.text: Can the audience raise hands if you seen the show already?

615.56.text: You create, upstage, tableaux that comment upon the action

621.66.text: that takes place closer to the audience.

625.54.text: It is a wonderful dialogue and we discovered quite late on in rehearsals actually that

636.00.text: inside the telling of the story,

639.64.text: that it's like a Greek chorus developed.

645.76.text: The only thing about Greek Chorus, I think,

649.65.text: is that if they're wearing masks is that they can't close their eyes.

654.58.text:
Therefore they have to look at
all this horror.

663.68.text: is that of course in the first half

666.84.text: it's full of opportunity and the

669.90.text: excitement of battle and valour and honour.

674.03.text:
Then the second half slowly and
inexorably takes us to the bloodbath of

682.56.text: those people in the village of Tafas and the 4000 Turkish soldiers who

689.16.text: were butchered, systematically butchered, as part of that particular campaign.

696.06.text: So the second half takes us inexorably towards this.

701.06.text:
We had, just there by that pillar
(which by the way supports the entire building)

709.40.text:
a Greek chorus of guys who couldn't
close their eyes.

719.24.text: They have to see all of these, terrible terrible things.

722.48.text: Like Lawrence saw all these terrible, terrible things.

725.02.text: It works wonderfully well, all of that.  I want to mention in passing

727.98.text: that the program for this show is particularly good.

731.60.text: It has two excellent essays, one by William Boyd and one by Dan Revelato on, respectively, TE Lawrence

738.38.text: and Terence Rattigan.  Could I just ask you a question about the  themes?

744.34.text: Those Essays touch upon those things

747.42.text: and Dan Revelato makes the point

749.92.text: that there are parallels between Rattigan's life and Lawrence's life.

752.72.text: Two things that I'd like you to consider are "celebrity" and being uncomfortable with it

757.56.text: and "repressed emotion" which has strong elements of this play

763.73.text: Those questions are so interesting because

767.39.text: one can see the the 1950s in a way, coming through this play.

782.14.text: It is particularly obviously 1950s from Rattigan's point of view.

788.12.text: The 1950s, a relatively short time after the Second World War.

792.88.text: A short time after the end of conscription.

798.77.text: Maybe even still conscription during the 1950s.

807.68.text: More particularly from Rattigan's point of view,

811.40.text: the fact that he and a close group of people had to effectively live a lie.

817.73.text: They were gay at a time when it was illegal.

823.97.text: Not illegal to be gay but illegal to act upon being gay.

831.38.text: So he obviously saw in Lawrence a kind of parallel figure.

834.59.text: Both of homosexuality but also a general thing of repression.

841.61.text: But what he does which is extraordinary is he delves deep, deep into the subject matter.

853.08.text: Because Lawrence was a Greek scholar and Lawrence seeks self-knowledge like a good Greek scholar.

867.44.text: But the the terrible irony is that Lawrence was physically abused.

876.38.text: So that, if you like, pollutes his sense of himself.

883.67.text:
So he can't deal with himself.  He needs to
become somebody else.

890.54.text: Could I take the second part, the repressed emotion a step further?

896.12.text: Drama, we're always told, is conflicts of strong personalities with competing objectives.

901.12.text:
So why is it that this repressed emotion
makes such a good subject for drama?

907.62.text: Well it isn't just in this play, you can see it in many, many plays.

918.23.text: The story of Lawrence is fascinating because

932.83.text: Also dealing with the rubbing together of the public and the private man.

939.82.text: This always makes marvelous drama.  The conflicts are sometimes with external agencies.

947.42.text: So with with the British Army for example.

949.54.text: When he wishes he no longer needed to act,

954.73.text: it's his duty that forces him to act.

959.56.text: It's his will that makes him act.

965.02.text: I'll put it this way. Running through the whole play there's an adventure story.

969.46.text: "Lawrence in Arabia", it's a big adventure story about what happened

973.75.text: There's a parallel emotional story of

979.12.text: how marvelous it was and then how shocking and appalling it became.

983.98.text:
So there are those two are overriding
arcs.

988.96.text: But at the same time there's this fascinating juxtaposition of the private man and the public man,

996.64.text: Of course Rattigan takes this from classical sources.

1002.04.text: Shakespeare made a living out of that.

1006.84.text: Henry V is based entirely upon the juxtaposition of the the private man expressed

1013.26.text: through his soliloquies and his fears of being a king and being a soldier

1016.92.text: and the public man who is required to do things that are very difficult and in the public glare.

1023.04.text:
I think those things, Rattigan and 
certainly Lawrence understood profoundly.

1029.64.text:
Can I quote one of the members of the
British forces who says;

1035.10.text: " I don't care what's right, the subtext is that it must be made to work"

1041.85.text: It's not whether or not it's right, this is our objective we must achieve that.

1046.26.text: Well that's war isn't it?  That's what has to happen in war.

1058.36.text: The lines just before that are quite interesting

1062.02.text: because he talks about Lawrence who was going to go back and fight.

1069.07.text:
He talks about "you must understand
what kind of a deserter you're sending back."

1074.16.text: Also what kind of war you're sending him back to.

1078.16.text: It's a situation devoid of heroism, or glory or honour.

1086.00.text: In that moment he's a wonderfully conflicted character

1090.88.text: who sees himself as a deserter as he goes back.

1094.60.text: Can I ask you a couple of questions about technical aspects of the production and how you developed it?

1103.54.text: where there are the English-speaking characters.

1115.87.text: Well we changed design about half way through

"I want you to put to put on Circus
Maximus".

1158.02.text: We've done that, you can't really see but it goes back to a semicircle in the back there.

1160.96.text: Then he came up with his marvelous seven pillars.

1164.62.text: We decided we would do even the English scenes, set in dreary old Uxbridge in December

1168.97.text: on this surface. Just as you would with a Shakespeare play.

1177.73.text: I'm tempted to ask our very erudite audience why there are seven pillars.

1182.23.text: But I'm not going to do that!

1183.57.text: Everybody speaks English all of the time

1191.46.text: So when you have transitions between what is English and then

1195.36.text: ostensibly Arabic conversation, how do you manage those moments of transition?

1200.56.text: We don't think about them a lot.

1204.54.text: The Arabs do you use an accent.

1209.42.text: Joseph doesn't except in one area of the play

1214.41.text: when he's talking to the Turkish officer he uses a

1220.71.text: slight accent when he is pretending to be an Arab.  That's the only time.

1230.16.text: or to people's enjoyment of the story.

1235.14.text: It just works as it is.

1237.18.text: The only thing we do however is we have one or two phrases in Arabic. That's really all we do.

1245.56.text: Also in Arabic you have some magnificent vocal music

1254.22.text: It also sometimes underscores the action.  How did you work that out?

1258.27.text: Some of them are mentioned in the script

1261.15.text: like the song that celebrates this great warrior.

1267.96.text: But we found , (my composer, Mia Soteriou, found) this extraordinary resource.

1279.03.text: I was completely ignorant of it.

1282.82.text: A resource of Arabic music, Arabic dance, Arabic song

1287.76.text: I knew nothing about it at all and it's fantastic.

1293.04.text: It's just an extraordinary cornucopia of art and Mia has taken that music,

1304.71.text: sometimes she's done her own thing with it.

1311.24.text: We use reasonably authentic film of the period

1317.78.text: all of which contributes to the mixed up thing of the dream.

1323.27.text: It was such a wonderful cultural resource.

the actors on stage.  They're perhaps

Mickey Feast's character, who has never

instead of the company coming together,
